sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: Good morning auntie!

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Morning auntie.

sentences.name: Auntie
sentences.sentence: Ah! Good morning Anna, Will. Welcome, welcome!

sentences.name: Auntie
sentences.sentence: Are you gonna buy the usual?

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: Yes, please!

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: I’m gonna wait outside.

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: You really need to get used to this smell. It’s just bread

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: I’ll go in with you when I have a cold or something.

sentences.name: Narator
sentences.sentence: The Store auntie prepares the usual thing that Anna bought and puts in an extra.

sentences.name: Auntie
sentences.sentence: Here you go, thank you for the purchase.

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: Wait, I didn't buy this one.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: Anna said, pointing at the extra bread in the plastic bags.

sentences.name: Auntie
sentences.sentence: It’s for him.

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: He doesn’t like the smell of bread, weird right? He'd eat it fine though

sentences.name: Auntie
sentences.sentence: Oh I’ve seen some customers like him, though i don’t get what they don’t like about the smell of freshly baked bread.

sentences.name: Auntie
sentences.sentence: But let’s get him used to it. Someday, maybe the two of you will dine in here together. And maybe have some of the other menu as well not just the bread

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: Yeah. . . I hope so, and maybe someday I can also tell him to get me some bread by himself.

sentences.name: Auntie
sentences.sentence: Hahaha ! Yeah, I guess you can do that too.

sentences.name: Auntie
sentences.sentence: Anyway,  that one is on the house, hope you continue buying from time to time

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: Thank you so much, auntie.

sentences.name: Narator
sentences.sentence: After that lovely talk and getting an extra from the bakery, Anna leaves the bakery with a smile. She goes to Will, who is waiting outside.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Are you done?

sentences.name: Narator
sentences.sentence: Anna reaches into the plastic bag and gives the extra croissant that the auntie gives her and gives it to Will.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Huh? I don’t want this one. Didn’t I tell you to buy the usual?

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: It’s an extra croissant from the auntie for you. It’s a HIGH QUALITY croissant and it’s free, so you better eat it.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Fine. . . Give it to me

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: You know I hope someday. . . Someday, you will always walk here alone. And gets me some high quality croiiisssant. Someday. . .

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: What are you talking about?

sentences.name: Narator
sentences.sentence: That was just a normal day. Anna loves her bread. But Will just does not like the smell, even though he can eat it just fine.

sentences.name: Narator
sentences.sentence: That should be one extremely forgettable memory of him and Anna walking together to get some bread. But he remembers. Even though he doesn’t want to.

sentences.name: Narator
sentences.sentence: Will continue his walk. Hoping that whatever memory about Anna or that bakery he has, he won’t accidentally remember it again.
